WhatsApp SMS Email Print Copy article link Save Alert Top Story RESTAURANT NEWS Ale Asylum co-founder opening Detroit-style pizza place on Madison's Near East Side Samara Kalk Derby | Wisconsin State Journal Jun 25, 2024 Jun 25, 2024 0 Facebook Twitter Bluesky WhatsApp SMS Email Print Copy article link Save The co-founder of the former Ale Asylum brewery is opening a pizza place at 912 E. Johnson St., where a Salvatore's Tomato Pies used to be. Otto Dilba said he's spent the past 15 months perfecting Detroit-style pizza in his home kitchen and plans to open Molten Monkey Pizza in late August or early September. Molten Monkey Pizza is going into the former Salvatore's Tomato Pies on Johnson Street. SAMARA KALK DERBY, STATE JOURNAL "I can't tell you how many different recipe formulations I've worked with," Dilba said, adding that Detroit pizza is tough to beat. "It's amazing to me just how many people have never even heard of the style and have never tried it." The pizzas, developed in 1946, are usually rectangular, at least an inch thick, and have caramelized cheese around the edges. Jet's Pizza, a Detroit pizza franchise, has been at 2831 Parmenter St. in Middleton since 2016 and Dilba said he's been a frequent customer. People are also reading… Wisconsin’s Powerball jackpot winners and how much they won Bankruptcy to leave large retail space empty in Madison John Nolen Drive reconstruction starts next month. Here’s what to know 16-story student apartment building proposed near State Street City, developer clash over partly demolished building on West Wilson Street Former Green Bay Packers QB cited after bar altercation in Eau Claire UW-Madison parents hire surrogate mom to care for students at college Survivors group says Madison Diocese ignored complaints against priest accused of sex crimes WIAA moves state high school team wrestling tournament out of Madison Restaurant reviews: Back for seconds, a look at 4 recently visited spots Which Madison schools saw the most police calls last year? 2 Marquette men's lacrosse players killed in crash near campus 5 must-see Wisconsin state parks to visit this fall Madison says GPA determines who gets automatic admission to UW, regardless of number of students Attorney who represented murderer Barbara Hoffman dies at 92 "I bet you I've paid many salaries there over the last few years — Jet's is great," Dilba said. Dilba said he's spent a lot of time working on the dough, which he called critical. "I wouldn't be doing this if I didn't think it was something that was worthy of pizza lovers and certainly the neighborhood," he said. Dilba, 50, who's from Tomahawk in Northern Wisconsin, spent about 22 years in the Orchard Ridge neighborhood and now lives in the Arbor Hills area. He said Tenney-Lapham has been one of his favorite neighborhoods in Madison since he moved here in the 1990s. "As far as sort of classic Madison neighborhoods, Tenney-Lapham has been at the top of my list for a long time. I love this neighborhood," he said. The restaurant has an indoor capacity of 50 with room for 20 outside. Movies-tv Wisconsin chef Dan Jacobs talks about his near win on 'Top Chef' Samara Kalk Derby | Wisconsin State Journal Salvatore's Tomato Pies owner Patrick DePula initially intended to keep the Johnson Street location, but the pandemic forced a change. The Johnson Street Salvatore's was DePula's second. His first one opened in Sun Prairie in 2011. Johnson Street came in late 2014 with a Monona location in 2020. In mid-February 2020, DePula and two partners opened DarkHorse by Sal's, a 3,400-square-foot restaurant on East Washington Avenue and Livingston Street. The restaurant was open for four weeks before it was forced to shut down indoor dining because of the pandemic. "I leased Livingston with the intent of that being a completely different restaurant. And COVID killed that," DePula said. "It was impossible to build a new brand during COVID." DePula consolidated both locations and turned DarkHorse into a Salvatore's. He closed Johnson Street in August 2021, reopened it briefly in 2022, but the remodeled space only lasted about nine months. He said it was too hard then to staff both locations. "I enjoyed it, but when we reopened it, it never was able to do what it did before COVID," he said. "It just didn't work to have those two spaces so close to each other." Meanwhile, Dilba co-founded Ale Asylum, the maker of Hopalicious, Ambergeddon and other popular beers, in 2006. It was put up for sale in 2021 and closed in 2022 after a purchase deal fell through. Last spring, the owners of Madison's Karben4 Brewing Co.  bought Ale Asylum's brands and recipes and have been carrying on many Ale Asylum products. Dilba said he's proud of what he did with Ale Asylum and intends to have some of it on tap at Molten Monkey. He said he plans to offer six to eight rotating tap beers, including Karben4. "We might even throw the occasional macro in there, you never know." His focus now is on getting the proper city permits so he can begin testing pizzas in the space. Local Greenbush Bar in Madison being sold after 30 years Samara Kalk Derby | Wisconsin State Journal Dilba said the menu will be small. "My thought has always been, the best places don't do 30 things, they do three things better than anyone." The menu also will have salads and appetizers. Dilba said he hasn't hired a chef yet. He said he has 16 to 18 specialty pizzas in the hopper and the one he's worked hardest on he's calling the Umami Bomby. It has three or four types of mushrooms, his signature cheese blend, garlic and truffle zest. He said moisture control has been challenging when it comes to that many mushrooms. Molten in the name comes from how Detroit pizzas look when they come straight from the oven, he said, and monkey is a nickname he's had for multiple people and animals he's loved in his life. "It's just an homage to them," Dilba said. The space is well set up for what he's trying to do and doesn't need any renovations, he said, adding that he needs to put his own aesthetic touch on it. "We're not going to open the doors until we have this thing exactly where we want it." 2024 Operational Referendum 2024 Facilities Referendum Public School Funding Home > ABOUT > Board of Education Board of Education About the Board of Education The Madison Board of Education is a seven-member policymaking body. Members are elected in April to serve staggered three-year terms in office. Our Strategic Framework lays out a roadmap for our work. Regular Board meetings are generally held on the last Monday of the month, beginning at 6 p.m. Special meetings and work groups typically hold meetings one a month. Contact the Board of Education To reach all seven board members, please use the following group e-mail address: board@madison.k12.wi.us . All Board of Education members will receive your email and may use it to inform their decisions and/or actions. Please know that a member of the Superintendent’s Team will receive and may respond to emails sent to this address. Meeting Agendas and Notices All Meeting Agendas and notices are hosted on BoardDocs (updated at noon on Fridays). Board Policies All board policies are hosted on BoardDocs. Board Meeting Access You can watch/listen to virtual meetings at the Madison Board of Education YouTube Channel . An archive of meetings is available as well. The community is invited to attend meetings in person at the Doyle Administration Building. Details about speaking to the Board or providing written comments during public input time are available on our website . Citizens' Ad Hoc Naming Committee - New southside elementary school Citizens' Ad Hoc Naming Committee - New southside elementary school Thanks to the community’s investment in our public schools during the 2020 referendum, the district constructed a new elementary school connected to Badger Rock Middle School. The new school, which opened fall 2023, has temporarily been called Southside Elementary until a permanent name is chosen. On Monday, May 6, the MMSD Board of Education voted to establish a 12-person committee for the purpose of naming the district's newest elementary school located at 501 E. Badger Road (currently referred to as Southside Elementary). The Ad Hoc Citizens’ Naming Committee is given the charge to follow Board Policy 6700 and move through the school naming process. This committee will follow the policy and make final recommendations to a Board of Education Work Group on the soonest date possible after the final meeting of this ad hoc committee. Get Directions “Our dough is “rested” for at least 48 hours before it is shaped and baked.” Our Story We opened in June, 2013. Owned and operated by Nicholas Mattioli and his friends and family . We do things different because our family prides ourselves in bringing true Neapolitan taste to the Madison community. OUR NAME NOVANTA Novanta ® (or “ninety” in Italian) refers to the ever-important ninety seconds that our authentic Neapolitan pizzas bake in our stone ovens before they are served hot and fresh to you. ANCIENT RECIPE INGREDIENTS Our pizzas all start with dough, based on an ancient Italian recipe that includes water, salt, yeast and 00 flour .  Our dough is “rested” for at least 48 hours before it is shaped and baked.  We offer only the finest and the freshest ingredients and toppings, including house-made mozzarella cheese. OUR OVENS COOKING The cooking of the pizza is as crucial as our ingredients.  Our oven, imported from Italy, is a centerpiece of our restaurant and heats to the ideal 900°F.  This enables our pizzas to cook to absolute perfection with the benefit of “oven spring,” which is caused by air and water vapor rapidly expanding inside the stretchy network of interconnected flour proteins that is the Novanta ® dough.  This means our dough inflates quickly, and thus ensures each pizza is light and airy, and is simply delicious. AUTHENTIC NEAPOLITAN PIZZAS AND MORE Novanta ® is pleased to offer guests authentic Neapolitan pizzas,  insalate (salads), dolci (desserts), and a fine assortment of beverages. article link Save Alert Top Story Topical STOUGHTON | FAMOUS YETI’S Famous Yeti's co-owner explains how THC got into pizzas Samara Kalk Derby | Wisconsin State Journal Oct 26, 2024 Oct 26, 2024 0 Facebook Twitter Bluesky WhatsApp SMS Email Print Copy article link Save The co-owner of a pizza restaurant in Stoughton that accidentally sickened customers with THC said the mistake happened when a worker borrowed some oil from a neighboring business, not knowing that it had been infused with Delta-9, the active ingredient in marijuana. Cale Ryan opened Famous Yeti's with his wife, Caitlin Ryan, in 2012. CAITLIN RYAN Cale Ryan owns Famous Yeti’s Pizza with his wife, Caitlin Ryan. The couple also run a separate commercial kitchen used by other businesses, including one that makes products with CBD and Delta-9. When Famous Yeti’s ran short of olive oil for its pizza dough on Tuesday, one of the cooks went across the hall to borrow some, Ryan said. 8 great restaurants you can find at Madison-area gas stations “It’s not normal to do, but you borrow a cup of sugar from a neighbor,” he said. “We went over to borrow some oil and grabbed the wrong one.” People are also reading… Wisconsin’s Powerball jackpot winners and how much they won Bankruptcy to leave large retail space empty in Madison John Nolen Drive reconstruction starts next month. Here’s what to know 16-story student apartment building proposed near State Street City, developer clash over partly demolished building on West Wilson Street Former Green Bay Packers QB cited after bar altercation in Eau Claire UW-Madison parents hire surrogate mom to care for students at college Survivors group says Madison Diocese ignored complaints against priest accused of sex crimes WIAA moves state high school team wrestling tournament out of Madison Restaurant reviews: Back for seconds, a look at 4 recently visited spots Which Madison schools saw the most police calls last year? 2 Marquette men's lacrosse players killed in crash near campus 5 must-see Wisconsin state parks to visit this fall Madison says GPA determines who gets automatic admission to UW, regardless of number of students Attorney who represented murderer Barbara Hoffman dies at 92 Ryan said it was one batch of dough, which can make 60 pizzas. They’ve heard from about 20 customers already, he said. Between that feedback and what he’s learned from Public Health Madison and Dane County, Ryan said there have been about 30 reported instances so far. People get more high than sick, he said. “They get really stoned. They get intoxicated from the THC, so I think it’s more alarming than anything to feel that way. It’s basically eating an edible, but without knowing.” Dining Famous Yeti's Pizza is back, with an arcade Samara Kalk Derby | Wisconsin State Journal The Ryans have four young children, and Ryan said they didn’t have any of the THC-infused pizza. But he said some children were affected and reported dizziness and tiredness. Ryan, who was at the restaurant when his employee borrowed the oil, said he has cooperated with the health department and police department. “So it’s all about us responding to the public now.” In an update posted on its website Friday , Public Health said the oil the employee took was in a clear plastic jug that looked like other cooking oils. “There was a label on the cap that had manufacturer’s information, use by date, and noted it contained Delta-9 cannabis,” the statement said. “The operator did not notice the label on the cap. There was no additional labeling on the body of the bottle.” People can legally purchase hemp-derived Delta-9 THC in Wisconsin as long as the THC concentration is at or below 0.3% dry weight. Ryan said his tenant’s Delta-9 is legal in Wisconsin but didn’t name the tenant. “His product is on the level. He’s the person who makes soap.” Paramedics took five people to the hospital after they reported eating at Famous Yeti’s, the health department said. Because of the symptoms, responders initially suspected possible carbon monoxide exposure and checked the restaurant for that. “Our staff contacted the area hospital and talked to a patient, who said the feeling felt similar to eating a THC edible,” the Public Health post said. “The patient was tested for THC, which came back positive.” FAMOUS YETI'S PIZZA Ryan said the support from his customers has been overwhelming. “It’s unfortunate for sure. And more than anything it’s betraying the public trust, which we’ve worked so hard to keep that good image.” Possible THC-related symptoms include dizziness, increased blood pressure, increased heart rate, nausea, vomiting, anxiety, panic attacks, paranoia, hallucinations, short-term memory impacts, time distortion and sleepiness, according to Public Health. “Keep in mind each person’s reaction may be different, and the concentration of THC in the pizza can vary by piece,” the health department said in an earlier posting. Late last year, Famous Yeti’s moved about two miles from its nearly 12-year-old location to a spot inside the mixed-use Stoughton Wellness and Athletic Center, 2300 Highway 51, where since 2020 the restaurant has been renting a commercial kitchen. The commercial kitchen the Ryans run is called STACK, for Stoughton Area Cooperative Kitchen, and it hosts about 12 food entrepreneurs. The Ryans also own the more upscale restaurant Wendigo, 121 E. Main St., which they opened in 2014. Public Health is asking those who ate the pizza and got sick to complete an online questionnaire to help with its investigation. They get intoxicated from the THC, so I think it's more alarming than anything to feel that way. It's basically eating an edible, but without knowing." 0 Comments Satisfy your cravings With our weekly newsletter packed with the latest in everything food. She would say, “Add in some passion when you cook.  You are not just cooking to eat, you are cooking to see the smiles of your family and friends.” Those special words from his cherished Nanny would stay with Joe his whole life. Joe imagined the day when he would carry on this tradition with a child of his own—and today his dream has been fulfilled. A little bit of Nanny, and a whole lot of love is being passed down to his beloved daughter Valentina.  She has been in the kitchen with her daddy since she could crawl. Her passion to learn and serve others is something that comes from her heart.  With Joe and Valentina pouring the love of family and friends into Valentina’s, everyone who breaks bread here is family. They invite you to come and eat, making your own traditions and memories with your family and friends. private events We host. You party! Marinara sauce poured over cheesy garlic breadsticks A bartender shaking a cocktail House-made Meatballs Eggplant Rollatini Classic Old Fashioned Moscow Mule Cannoli Flight Classic Daiquiri award-winning pizza Reviews Review by - Yelp Michael R: Had a lovely experience here. Got seated quickly, server was extremely friendly and nice. Food was phenomenal! It was a show just watching them make pizzas and baking them like it was nothing special. Every single pizza looked delicious and makes us want to come back really soon. We will be trying everything on the menu. Easily the best pizza place in the Huntsville Madison area and worth the drive no matter how far. Review by - Yelp Robert R: If you enjoy great NY style wood fired Napolitano pizza this is the best place in Huntsville/Madison for fantastic pizza. Salads, and meatballs are very good as well, and the cannoli's are awesome! Staff is friendly, service is excellent, and the owner is hands on, and involved in all aspects of the operation, and it shows. Review by - Yelp Robin Y: Got there on a Thursday around 5:30 and was immediately seated! Service was great- waiter was knowledgeable and helpful. Food was fresh, the garlic knots are the best we have ever had and the marinara sauce was definitely home made and fresh, so good! Pizza was great and the crust was perfect. We will be back! Review by - Yelp Futien J: WOW!!  As a Chicago native, this nails it!  We came by as a recommendation by friends and we couldn't be any more thankful!  The pizza was so light , crisp and flavorful.  It's been a long time since I've enjoyed a pizza like this!  The staff and owner were very gracious and so friendly.  This is my news favorite! Review by - Yelp Steve B: Amazing all around, service food, environment, cleanliness. Best Pizza in all off Alabama!!! Hands down!! I only eat pizza here at any time.
